objectives.description: Create effective strategies for preparing for job interviews, including research, practice, and logistics planning.
Practice responding to common interview questions using the proven STAR method framework.
Comprehend professional workplace expectations, etiquette, and communication skills that employers value.
Learn techniques for managing interview anxiety and master post-interview follow-up strategies.

terms.definition: An interview approach focused on how candidates handled specific situations in the past to predict future performance.
terms.example: "Tell me about a time when you had to resolve a conflict with a coworker."

terms.definition: A structured technique for answering behavioral questions: Situation, Task, Action, and Result.
terms.example: Provides clear, organized responses with concrete evidence of your capabilities.

terms.definition: An interview conducted by multiple interviewers at once, often including team members, managers, and HR.
terms.example: Make eye contact with the person asking each question but include others in your responses.

terms.definition: Expected behaviors in workplace settings that demonstrate respect, courtesy, and professionalism.
terms.example: Punctuality, appropriate attire, active listening, respectful communication, thank-you notes.

leftPanel.title: Preparation Is Your Competitive Edge
paragraphs: Effective interview preparation involves researching the company, understanding the position, practicing responses, and planning logistics.
Well-prepared candidates demonstrate initiative and genuine interest‚Äîtwo qualities employers highly value.

highlightBox.text: � Research shows that prepared candidates are 2-3x more likely to receive job offers than unprepared ones.

stats.label: Fail for Lack of Knowledge About Company in {{STATE_NAME}}

paragraphs: Describe the context or background of the specific event or situation you're discussing
Explain your responsibility or role in that situation‚Äîwhat were you expected to do?
Detail the specific actions YOU took to address the task‚Äîfocus on your contributions
Share the outcomes of your actions‚Äîuse specific metrics and numbers when possible

leftPanel.title: Know What to Expect
paragraphs: Different interview formats require different preparation strategies. Understanding the format helps you prepare appropriately.
One-on-One: Focus on building rapport with a single interviewer. Most common format.
Panel: Multiple interviewers‚Äînote names and roles for follow-up.
Virtual: Test technology, ensure good lighting, look at camera.

highlightBox.text: � Virtual interviews now account for 86% of first-round interviews at major companies.

layoutData.title: First Impressions Are Formed in Seconds
paragraphs: Research shows that interviewers form initial impressions within 7 seconds. Your appearance and body language communicate confidence, professionalism, and reliability before you say a word.
bulletPoints: Greeting: Firm handshake, warm smile, confident posture
Posture: Sit straight but comfortable, slightly lean forward
Eye Contact: Maintain natural eye contact without staring
Hand Placement: Rest on table or lap, avoid crossed arms
Dress Code: One level above everyday attire for the position
Speaking Pace: Moderate pace with clear articulation

keyPoint.text: ‚ö†Ô∏è Avoid: Fidgeting, checking phone/watch, slouching, excessive gestures, crossing arms defensively

leftPanel.title: Nervous? That's Normal!
paragraphs: Interview anxiety is completely natural‚Äîit shows you care about the opportunity. The key is managing it effectively so it doesn't interfere with your performance.
Preparation is your best weapon against anxiety. When you know your material, you can focus on connecting with the interviewer.

highlightBox.text: üßò Deep breathing before interviews can reduce anxiety by up to 40% and improve cognitive performance.

infoCard.title: Anxiety Management Tips:
items: Get good sleep the night before

layoutData.title: Interviews Are Your Gateway to Career Success
paragraphs: Interview skills are career-long assets. Whether you're applying for your first job, seeking a promotion, or pivoting to a new career, your ability to present yourself confidently and competently will determine your opportunities.
bulletPoints: Career Entry: Strong interviews open doors to better starting positions
Salary Negotiation: Confident candidates earn 7-10% more in starting salary
Promotions: Internal candidates interview too‚Äîsame skills apply
Career Pivots: Transferable skills require clear articulation
Networking: Every professional conversation is a mini-interview
Client Relationships: First impressions extend to business development

keyPoint.text: üí∞ The Financial Impact: A strong first job can set your salary trajectory for years. Starting $5,000 higher can mean $500,000+ over a career.

leftPanel.title: Demonstrate Your Interest
paragraphs: Preparing thoughtful questions shows you've done your research and are seriously evaluating the opportunity‚Äînot just hoping for any offer.
Great questions reveal your understanding of the role and help you determine if this is the right fit for your career goals.

scenario.name: Jamie's STAR Method Success in {{STATE_NAME}}
paragraphs: Jamie interviewed for a marketing assistant position. When asked "Tell me about a time you worked under a tight deadline," she used the STAR method to structure her response:
Before STAR: "I'm good under pressure and have worked on lots of tight deadlines."

With STAR: "During my internship, our team was asked to create a social media campaign in 5 days instead of 3 weeks. I created a day-by-day schedule, completed all 10 posts ahead of schedule, and the client approved without revisions."

takeaways.title: Preparation Is Everything
